I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  countries  have  a  vision  of  becoming  a 
prosperous, integrated, and harmonious subregion. To achieve this vision, they have adopted a 
strategy to enhance connectivity, improve competitiveness, and promote a sense of community. 
In particular, they are committed to intensifying their efforts in nine priority sectors and three 
priority geographical areas. The GMS North South Economic Corridor (NSEC) is one of the 
three priority areas.1 Geographically, the NSEC embraces the area along the main north–south 
transport routes that link the economic hubs in the central and northern areas of the GMS 
subregion.2 
 
2.  A number of major infrastructure investments are already being undertaken by GMS 
countries in the NSEC and more are planned. The physical connectivity of the corridor will be 
significantly improved upon the completion of these infrastructural investments. The improving 
infrastructure, coupled with expanded cross-border cooperation among the GMS countries, will 
accelerate the process of integrating the NSEC's economic structures into both the rest of the 
subregion and the rest of the world. To reap the substantial potential benefits, GMS countries 
along the NSEC need to have a clearer understanding of the opportunities and challenges that 
will arise from the economic integration process. The NSEC requires a well thought out strategy 
to promote sustainable development and ensure that the economic growth brought about by 
increased integration generates benefits for the people without degrading the environment. To 
increase its competitiveness, the NSEC needs to identify the areas where it enjoys comparative 
advantages and promote private sector development in those areas. Greater efforts must be 
made to improve the level and frequency of the interaction between the public and private 
sectors, and to mobilize both public and private resources to help realize the NSEC’s potential. 
 
3.  At  the  request  of  the  GMS  governments,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will 
conduct a development study3 to help the NSEC identify and address major development issues 
through  a  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  project.  The  concept  of  the  project  was 
endorsed by the GMS leaders at the Second GMS Summit in July 2005. To prepare the project, 
ADB  missions  visited  GMS  countries  and  held  discussions  with  government  officials, 
representatives from development institutions, private sector entities, and civil society groups 
concerning the objectives, scope, financing, and implementation arrangements of the RETA 
project.4 The RETA’s design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  There are many challenges facing the NSEC at this early stage in its development. The 
challenges are likely to become more formidable as economic integration continues. Therefore, 
a priority of the RETA will be to identify and analyze the major issues that could constrain the 
NSEC, and formulate a strategy to address those issues. 
 
5.  In the 13 years since the launch of the GMS economic cooperation program, GMS 
countries have demonstrated strong political goodwill in cooperating to achieve the goal of 
common prosperity. The GMS program features a set of cooperation platforms at various levels. 
                                                           
1   The other two are the East–West and Southern Economic Corridors. 
2  However, the investment study of the North South Economic Corridor (NSEC) will focus mainly on areas along the 
routes from Chiang Rai, Thailand, to Kunming, People’s Republic of China (PRC); Kunming to Hai Phong, Viet 
Nam; and Nanning, PRC, to Hanoi, Viet Nam. 
3  ADB financed a similar study for the GMS East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC) in 1999. 
4  The RETA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 14 March 2005.

2   
   
These platforms link, for instance, top leaders and ministers, senior officials and working group 
experts,  governments  and  development  partners,  and  governments  and  private  sector 
representatives—including those from civil society. Significant progress has been made as a 
result  of  these  cooperation  platforms.  For  instance,  GMS  countries  have  begun  to  clearly 
recognize their increasing interdependence and the importance of aligning their development 
strategies to harness the benefits of economies of scale. Cooperation and coordination at the 
government  level  has also  led  to  concrete  achievements  such  as the  GMS  Cross  Border 
Transport Agreement. 
 
6.  In the NSEC, however, much remains to be done to take full advantage of the increased 
commitment to cooperation demonstrated by the GMS countries. In particular, there is an 
opportunity for more effective private sector participation in the cooperation platforms. There is a 
need to develop other mechanisms to translate the political goodwill into economic cooperation 
at specific locations. These mechanisms should enhance public–private partnerships through 
ongoing, effective dialogue. These mechanisms also should closely link local and international 
institutions and development experts. Such linkages would better utilize local knowledge and 
reflect local needs, while at the same time helping to introduce best international practices and 
management know-how into the development of the NSEC.  
 
7.  In developing the NSEC, it will be important to ensure that no investment gaps arise that 
prevent key infrastructure investments from yielding their full benefits. Similarly, corresponding 
measures may be needed to facilitate the use of the infrastructure and reduce the underlying 
transaction costs. 
 
8.  To accelerate the economic development of the NSEC, it will be important to increase 
the currently weak levels of private sector participation and investment in the corridor. Limited 
public resources alone cannot drive the growth of the NSEC. There is no lack of enthusiasm to 
attract foreign direct investment (FDI) in the corridor. However, there is lack of knowledge about 
who the potential foreign direct investors are and what sectors they might invest in. This points 
to a need to come up with a mechanism to communicate with potential foreign direct investors 
on a regular basis in order to better understand their needs and interests. Such a mechanism 
will help NSEC governments tailor their policies to draw more FDI, while helping potential 
investors better understand both the investment opportunities available to them and the laws 
that regulate investments. This RETA will, therefore, explore the feasibility of developing—and 
subsequently piloting—an institutional network to enhance public–private partnerships in the 
NSEC. 
 
9.  Encouraging foreign direct investors to remain is as important as attracting them in the 
first place. As private investment increases, potential disputes between private and sovereign 
entities will also likely arise. Experience elsewhere in the world indicates that it is important to 
have a scheme in place to mediate such disputes (a mediation-service scheme). For this 
purpose, GMS countries should engage only independent experts with proven track records in 
mediating investment disputes and preventing them from becoming politicized. If well structured, 
a mediation-service scheme can play an important role in improving the investment climate in 
GMS countries. The issue of creating a GMS investment mediation-service scheme will be 
examined under a separate GMS RETA. The investment mediation scheme, if implemented, 
could also help improve the investment climate of the NSEC.

3
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The ultimate goal in developing the NSEC is to enhance economic development in the 
area and thereby improve the living standards of the people both in the corridor and elsewhere 
in the GMS. The purpose of the RETA is to accelerate the process of turning the north–south 
transport corridor into an economic corridor where the movement of goods, people, and capital 
within and across the subregion can take place with optimum economic and development 
benefits. The RETA will help identify the major development issues facing the NSEC and 
formulate a medium-term development strategy for the sustainable development of the NSEC. It 
will  also  help  strengthen  the  interaction  between  the  public  and  private  sectors,  thereby 
enhancing  their  mutual  understanding  and  dialogue  and  promoting  timely  and  efficient 
investment in the corridor. 
 
11.  The RETA will be results oriented. The major outputs of the RETA will be in the following 
three areas. First, it will prepare an issues paper analyzing the major development issues and 
challenges facing the corridor in the medium term. Second, it will prepare a development 
strategy for the NSEC that will identify priority sectors and come up with an indicative list of 
major potential public and private investment projects in those priority sectors. Third, it will 
explore  the  feasibility  of  designing  an  institutional  network5 linking  selected  local  research 
institutes  and/or  universities,  private  entities,  and  business  entrepreneurs.  Such  a  network 
would  promote  regular  exchanges  of  views  and  information  between  policy  makers  and 
investors on issues related to trade facilitation, investment, and private sector development. The 
network would also help disseminate the network partners’ working results, create opportunities 
to cooperate, and encourage partners to follow up on the outputs from this RETA.6 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  A number of reports and studies, completed and ongoing, have covered some aspects 
of economic integration in the NSEC and the GMS at large. The GMS transport-sector strategy, 
tourism-sector  strategy,  the  Strategic  Framework  for  Action  on  Trade  Facilitation  and 
Investment, the Cross-Border Transport Agreement, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
(Lao PDR) northern area development strategy, and private sector assessments of each GMS 
country are just a few examples. The RETA will build on the information and recommendations 
of these studies to formulate a coherent and coordinated development program for the NSEC.  
 
13.  The  RETA  will  focus  on  economic  integration  issues  in  the  area  of  the  NSEC. 
Specifically, it will examine how and to what extent the corridor is currently interlinked in terms 
of infrastructure, trade, and investment, and it will identify how such linkages are likely to 
change  in  the  medium  term.  The  infrastructural  integration  analysis  will  include  linkages 
involving roads, railways, waterways, and air transport. The trade integration analysis will look at 
what commodities are being traded, whether commodities are being sold for transit or for final 
consumption,  and  the  significance  of  trade  in  the  corridor’s  development.  The  investment 
integration analysis will identify potential major foreign direct investors in the NSEC, sectors 
likely to draw FDI, and mechanisms that will encourage private sector investment. 
                                                           
5  During the preparation of the RETA project, the ADB fact-finding mission met local institutions and private entities 
to discuss the concept of the network. The response received was positive and encouraging. 
6  One of the lessons identified from previous ADB operations, including the EWEC pre-investment study, was to 
avoid activities that are not sustainable after the completion of the RETA. This highlights the importance of 
developing the institutional network.

4   
   
 
14.  In addressing these issues, the RETA will also examine if there are legal, policy, or 
institutional constraints that may impede integration. Based on this analysis, the RETA will 
prepare an issues paper highlighting the major physical and non-physical constraints impeding 
the corridor’s infrastructure, trade, and investment linkages. It will further identify priority sectors 
for the corridor’s development based on underlying comparative advantages, and will help 
identify an indicative list of major potential projects for investments by both the public and 
private sectors. It will prepare a development strategy to promote investment in the NSEC and 
help attract financing for the identified list of major investment projects. 
  
15.  The identification and preparation of investment projects and priorities is important and 
must  take  into  account  local  views  and  circumstances.  In  addition,  promoting  investment, 
particularly private investment, is both a long-term task and a dynamic process, especially given 
the pace of change in the GMS. Against this background, the RETA will engage local experts to 
work with international experts during the implementation period. It will also aim to develop an 
institutional network, involving local institutions and private entities, for promoting investment in 
the NSEC on a long-term basis. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the proposed RETA is estimated at $630,000 equivalent. The RETA will 
be financed by the PRC Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, funded by the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China in an amount not exceeding $400,000, to be 
administered by ADB, and by ADB's TA funding program for $200,000. GMS governments will 
provide the equivalent of $30,000 in kind. The respective GMS authorities will also assist with 
identification of local institutes and/or universities and business entities to participate in the 
proposed institutional network, and assist in organizing workshops to discuss and disseminate 
the RETA findings and recommendations. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are 
presented in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB’s  Operations  Coordination  Division  (MKOC),  Mekong  Department,  will  be  the 
Executing  Agency  responsible  for  implementation  of  the  RETA.  MKOC  will  cooperate  and 
coordinate  closely  with  ADB  resident  missions  in  the  GMS  countries  concerned  during 
implementation. The GMS national secretariats in each country will act as national focal points 
for  the  implementation  of  the  RETA.  They  will  also  facilitate  the  process  of  broad-based 
consultation and participation in their respective countries. 
 
18.  The  RETA  will  be  implemented  by  a  team  of  individual  international  and  local 
consultants under the guidance of ADB and in close consultation with the national focal points. 
ADB will select and engage the individual consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic 
consultants. A total of 11 person-months of international consultants’ services will be required, 
involving intermittent inputs by two individual consultants. A total of 40 months of domestic 
consultant inputs will be required. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are presented 
in Appendix 3. The RETA will be implemented over a period of 20 months and is expected to be 
completed at end of September 2007.

5
 
19.  The  RETA  will  arrange  up  to  three  regional  workshops  to  discuss  its  findings  and 
recommendations. In addition, the RETA will include national and local workshops to promote 
participation and dialogue with the community and interest groups along the NSEC.  
 
21.  A final report will be printed and disseminated upon completion of the RETA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the PRC Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund 
funded by the Government of the People’s Republic of China; and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000, on a grant basis for the Greater Mekong 
Subregion: Development Study of the North South Economic Corridor, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of individual consultants will be engaged for this regional technical assistance 
(RETA) project. A total of 51 person-months of consulting services will be required, including 11 
person-months of international consultants and 40 person-months of domestic consultants. The 
consultants will report to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) task manager for the project. The 
indicative person-month allocations and terms of reference are set out below. 
A.  International Consultants 
  1.  Development Economist/Team Leader (7 person-months) 
2.  The  team  leader  will  help  the  ADB  task  manager  provide  overall  direction  to  the 
international  and  domestic  consultants  and  coordinate  and  supervise  the  work  of  other 
consultants  recruited  under  the  RETA.  He  or  she  will  be  responsible  for  coordinating  the 
preparation and submission of all RETA outputs to ADB in accordance with the agreed schedule. 
 
3.  The responsibilities of the team leader will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  Closely  review  existing  reports  and  studies  (by  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
[GMS]  countries, ADB, and others) that are relevant to the RETA, with an aim 
toward understanding the challenges, identifying the gaps in investment and 
policy making, and looking at ways to build linkages. 
 
(ii)  Identify the major development issues facing the North South Economic Corridor 
(NSEC) and define the corridor's strategic position, strengths, and weaknesses 
relative  to  the  rest  of  the  GMS,  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations 
(ASEAN), Asia, and the world. 
 
(iii)  Prepare a detailed outline of an issues paper examining potential linkages in 
infrastructure, trade, and investment to guide the work of subsequent domestic 
consultants; refine the outline during and after the initial visits to GMS countries. 
 
(iv)  Prepare an issues paper with inputs from international and domestic consultants. 
 
(v)  Identify potential priority sectors along each transport route of the NSEC, and 
help prepare a development strategy paper to promote the development of these 
identified priority sectors with inputs from international and domestic consultants. 
 
(vi)  Draw up an indicative list of major potential investment projects in the identified 
priority sectors, defining clearly the criteria for inclusion of projects in the list, and 
draw up a separate list of potential major foreign direct investors that are active 
and interested in the region. 
 
(vii)  Prepare a template for a cooperation agreement by ADB with selected local 
institutes and business associations; define the potential scope and forms of 
such cooperation.

(viii)  Identify potential partners for an institutional network.1  
 
(ix)  Prepare regular (at least quarterly) brief progress reports and/or work plans to 
keep interested parties apprised of the RETA implementation status and issues 
that potentially need to be addressed. 
 
(x)  Identify potential topics related to trade facilitation and investments that are

accordingly. 
 
(xi)  Plan and organize the workshops with the help of domestic consultants and

(xii)  Liaise with all other consultants to ensure that their individual inputs and work

availability. 
 
(xiv)  Finalize the RETA reports for publication or dissemination and carry out other 
duties and tasks that may be required by ADB. 
 
4.  The team leader must have (i) a good understanding of development and proven ability 
to capture the strategic issues for the development of an area where there are competing needs 
and multiple challenges; (iii) demonstrated ability to help formulate a development strategy to 
address the identified issues; (iv) at least 15 years of working experience in development; (v) 
post-graduate  degree  in  economics;  (vi)  familiarity  with  the  issues  and  major  institutional 
arrangements for economic cooperation in the GMS subregion; (vii) considerable subregional 
experience, including at least two substantive assignments in GMS countries; (viii) the capacity 
to work efficiently and effectively with national counterparts and domestic consultants; and (ix) 
excellent communication skills in both writing and speaking; (x) strong interpersonal skills; and 
(xi)  demonstrated  team  leadership  capacity.  Working  knowledge  of  subregional  languages 
would be useful. 
 
  2.  Trade Economist/Private Sector Development Expert (4 person-months) 
5.  The person will work closely with the team leader, especially in the areas of trade 
facilitation, investment, and private sector development. He or she will be one of the major 
contributors to the issues paper and development strategy papers and is expected to help guide 
domestic consultants in related areas. The tasks of the consultant will include the following: 
 
                                                           
1  Institutional network partners may come from local research institutes, universities, chambers of commerce or 
other private and nongovernmental entities that are active in researching and promoting subregional trade and 
investments. The institutional network will not require creation of any new institution. It will be developed on a 
mutual-benefit basis from existing institutions. The partners under the institutional network are expected to 
regularly exchange views and information mainly in the area of trade facilitation and investment, help disseminate 
outcome of co-partners’ work, and collaborate to undertake studies and projects jointly or on a parallel basis.  The 
institutional network will also help promote dialogue between the government and private sector.

12  Appendix 3   
(i)  Identify the major issues related to trade facilitation and investment in order to 
provide analyses of the following: which goods are being traded and for what 
purpose; how is trade significant in the development of the NSEC and the region; 
what trade policy and non-trade policy barriers are impeding trade. 
 
(ii)  Identify  the  reasons  why  private  investment  has  been  weak  in  the  corridor; 
identify which sectors along each route of the corridor have the potential to 
attract foreign direct investment; make recommendations on how the corridor and 
the subregion at large can encourage more foreign direct investment. 
 
(iii)  Review and assess existing strategies and plans for industrial development in 
areas  such  as  industrial  estates,  export  processing  zones,  mining,  tourism, 
communications,  and  power,  and  identify  the  priority  sectors  that  may  have 
comparative advantage and have potential to attract foreign direct investment.  
 
(iv)  Help prepare the outline of the issues paper and guide domestic consultants 
accordingly, especially in the related specialized areas.  
 
(v)  Help compile an indicative list of major investment projects in priority sectors 
along each transport route of the NSEC, help compile the list of major potential 
foreign direct investors, and discuss the issue of investment modalities to finance 
the identified investment projects. 
 
(vi)  Help identify local institutions and private entities with which ADB may enter into 
agreements  for  regular  cooperation;  help  define  the  areas  and  forms  of 
cooperation. 
 
(vii)  Organize workshops and meetings, prepare RETA reports, conduct field visits, 
and  consult  with  relevant  line  ministries  and  other  government  agencies, 
provincial authorities, business councils, and other community organizations. 
 
(viii)  Assist the team leader in assessing data needs and providing advisory support 
to domestic consultants. 
 
(ix)  Examine whatever formal or informal institutional mechanisms may exist for 
public–private consultation, and make suggestions on improving or developing 
mechanisms to promote public–private partnerships. 
 
(x)  Help finalize RETA reports for publication and/or dissemination, and carry out 
other duties and tasks that may be required by the ADB task manager. 
 
6.  The successful candidate will (i) have at least 10 years experience working on trade 
facilitation and investment; (ii) have post-graduate qualifications in economics, business, law, or 
related fields; (iii) understand the issues and practices of free trade and investment protection 
agreements in the region and in the world, and understand the potential implications of these 
agreements in the GMS; (ii) be familiar with the major institutional arrangements for economic 
cooperation in the region; (iv) have substantive experience working in GMS countries; and (v) 
have a good understanding of the private sector’s needs and constraints. He or she must have 
command of English and strong interpersonal skills. Working experience and knowledge in a 
potential priority sector (e.g., agriculture, industry, tourism, or energy) would be a plus.

Appendix 3  13 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
1.  Development Economist/Specialist (4 person-months per country, for a total of 
20 person months) 
7.  The responsibilities of the development economists/specialists will include, but not be 
limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  Identify the major issues facing the corridor within his or her own country and 
identify existing studies that may be relevant to the RETA. 
 
(ii)  Contribute to the preparation of the draft issues paper. 
 
(iii)  Contribute to the preparation of the draft development strategy paper. 
 
(iv)  Assist in planning and organizing workshops and meetings. 
 
(v)  Help identify local institutes and private entities that might potentially cooperate 
with ADB. 
 
(vi)  Help identify the major local and international investors. 
 
(vii)  Help  identify  the  priority  sectors  and  draw  up  an  indicative  list  of  major 
investment projects in those priority sectors. 
 
(viii)  Collect and compile necessary information and data to support the study. 
 
(ix)  Make suggestions on how to enhance public–private partnerships and enhance 
private investments. 
 
(x)  Assist  the  team  leader  and  other  international  consultants  in  making  local 
consultations,  preparing  relevant  reports,  and  carrying  out  other  tasks  as 
required. 
 
The  domestic  development  economists/specialists  must  have  at  least  10  years 
experience working on development and have a thorough understanding of the local 
economic issues, policies, regulations, and institutional framework of policy making. 
They should be familiar with the major initiatives in subregional cooperation and have a 
post-graduate degree or equivalent in economics, business, or a related field. They 
should have prior experience working with international institutions and consultants. 
They must have a good understanding of local private sector development issues and 
constraints. Good written and oral communication skills and good interpersonal skills 
are essential. 
 
  2.  Unallocated Domestic Experts (total of 20 person-months) 
 
8.  Twenty person-months of domestic consulting services are budgeted to (i) address data 
gaps and other unexpected issues that might arise, and (ii) support further development of 
investment projects or related policy issues that, proposed by the institution network partners, 
have the potential to be taken up by private investors or for policy issues, to be considered by

14  Appendix 3   
relevant policy makers. Detailed terms of reference for such tasks will be prepared as the needs 
are identified during implementation of the RETA. 
 
C.  Resource Person 
9.  The RETA plans to organize two to three workshops to discuss the RETA’s findings and 
recommendations. In addition, the RETA will also help organize meetings to discuss specific 
investment proposals that may emerge and be deemed worthy of pursuing over the course of 
RETA  implementation.  Depending  on  the  situation,  resource  persons  may  be  engaged  as 
experts to attend the workshops and/or meetings. The resource persons must prepare and 
submit to ADB for prior approval papers related to the topics of discussion before attending the 
above-mentioned workshops or meetings. The RETA will aim to engage only identified experts 
to attend these workshops and meetings, and will fund only their participation in the meetings, 
not their preparation of papers or other presentation materials.
